posts.html:
It's hard to say exactly when the idea to move overseas first spawned. One thing is certain - it started with me and it had been a yearning dream from yesteryear.

Back when we were dating, I mentioned to Claudia that one day I'd love to live overseas. We almost broke up because of that. The concept of moving overseas was abhorrent to her. We were at different stages of our goals.

For me, I think at some point on the precipice adulthood, I began to entertain visions of a life lived abroad or at least a life lived outside of Melbourne; outside of my comfort zone.

I think the very first seed that was planted was when I travelled with my family to the US. We were in the streets of New York when my uncle's brother who was a local said I could pass as a New Yorker. I never gave it much thought but I do believe it laid down the groundwork for more inspiration over the next decade.

To my parents the idea had been preposterous. Why would you leave everything behind? Why leave a cushy job earning a six figure salary? Why leave all your loving family behind? What are you going to do about your mortgage? What are you going to do about your cat? What about having kids? What about all your friends?

A good quality of life was paramount to my parents values and unarguably so.
They come from a time and generation that really left them no choice but to go out and seek a better life. My dad grew up as poor can be; ascending nearby hills with his brothers to cut and harvest woodfire in order to cook food. My mum grew up in the slums of Manilla where family was the only thing that formed an impenetrable sense of drive for survival.

And in this case, that's the key - survival. Both our had left their homes to seek survival. It was in their best interest to move.

Today however, whilst it is also in our best interest to move, the motives behind our interest is more about opportunity than it is about survival. We now live in an age that is experiencing new levels of peace & prosperity and so instead of survival, we seek  opportunity. And at the end of the day, humans are nomadic in nature.

When I finally happened upon this paradigm and explained it to my parents, it was well understood and no additional explanation was required.

In retrospect, I have tried to best rationalise the culmination of our recent move and I think it largely boils down to few moments:

In 2015, I travelled to the south island of New Zealand with my old friend Rob Tran. Curiously, experiencing the gorgeous southern alps & lakes that dotted the Canterbury and Otago regions in New Zealand were not the deciding factor to upheave our lives but it was rather the sheer distinction between what I had known for so long and what could possibly be.

Put simply, "if this is what another place is like, what more the rest of the world?".

The other contributing factor was how much I grown to despise Melbourne's, and by extension, Australia's inability to think big and make some waves in the world.
"She'll be right mate" is the embodiment of the Aussie attitude and it has kept us easy-going for a long time but it's also kept us apathetic and I couldn't see myself putting up with it for much longer.

The long and short of it is this: I have felt out of touch and lost my sense of belonging to a city and nation that has collectively lost it's sense of identity in the world and the ramifications of this have cascaded into the everyman's way of life. I'm a person that is big on vision, I look for it everywhere. I look for friends that have vision, I want to work for organisations that have big vision, I want to be a part of a church has vision for the modern age, I want to be part of a nation that has big vision for playing its part in the rest of the world. And sadly, Australia is not in tune with that wavelength and hopefully someday it might but I can't be waiting around for that to happen. The time is now.

So these philosophies installed themselves quite deeply into my head and I began to look on with envy at cities and nations all over the globe and marvelled at how progressive and innovative they were trying to be.

Just take a quick look at Europe, particularly with the recent introduction of the GDPR (https://eugdpr.org/)(General Data Protection Regulation) - while it's not perfect, it is an incredible step forward in terms of protecting the rights and privacy of all Europeans. Meanwhile in Australia we have just passed the most backward-stepping piece of legislation the world has ever seen, the Anti-Encryption Law (https://fee.org/articles/australia-s-unprecedented-encryption-law-is-a-threat-to-global-privacy/).

I digress. Ultimately, the grass was really green on the other side and I had to get there.

Fast forward to our honeymoon in Europe in 2016. We merely experienced a small taste but it was enough to convince us that we wanted to live in a place like Germany. We loved the cultural ethos, the intuitive & innovative way of life, the rich history, the proximity to other beautiful neighbouring countries, and most importantly, the autobahn.

And so we agreed to move overseas and begin our grand plans to move to Germany. We started by researching work life, making connections with people and started learning German. At first it we convinced ourselves it was doable. German's can speak English but it's not the official language.

Over time, we began to realise the futility of trying to move to country that spoke a different language. We would need to learn, not only the common tongue, but learn to speak it in a professional setting; Claudia would need to learn medical German.

So we re-evaluated our plans. If language was the barrier, the only other place to go was the UK. This is fine. We'd love to go to there. So I began throwing questions to my English colleague at the time and asked about living in Manchester.

For some reason I was convinced that Manchester would be a cool place to live. It was fast becoming a centre for culture and tech in the north of England. Also, it's not London so it shouldn't be that expensive to live there. My colleague didn't discourage me but did make me wary of the extremities of the weather up north. It can get incredibly cold.

Never mind that because recruiters started getting in touch with me about tech jobs in Manchester - though they never really progressed because I didn't have a visa yet which I'll talk more about in another post soon.

Fast forward a period of time and we eventually decided that London would have to be the place to aim for. There would be a better chance of getting work (although just as much competition). If we could just get jobs that paid enough for us to live in central London, we would be happy. So we planned a mid-year getaway to London with the aim of scouting the city for liveability.

In June 2018, we were the upper deck of a new Routemaster heading to South Kensington  station when Claudia decided to google the idea of applying for a nursing job in London. Lo and behold, she stumbled upon a website of an organisation that did exactly what we were looking for - they would recruit nurses from overseas to work in London and the rest of the UK. They would take care of the entire process (thankfully - what a process it was!).

When we arrived back home in Melbourne, Claudia spared no time in enquiring and by the end of August 2018, Claudia received a formal letter of offer from a hospital in Chelsea that specialised in cardiology.

And so the journey officially begun.

posts.html:
To be perfectly honest, the only reason we flew into Munich was purely due to it being the cheapest option. Though I’m not quite sure why. It may have something to do with less taxes or fees when flying in and out of the Eurozone from Munich.

With that said, I absolutely love Munich. There’s something about it that has a certain charm to it. I think a large part of that could be attributed to its vast and eclectic history. Nothing a couple of world wars can’t do to add to your nation’s history.

We flew out of Melbourne W-DAY +1 at 1400 hours and landed at Munich W-DAY +2 at 0700 hours local time so it worked out well and calibrated to the timezone with no jet laggage.

Claudia was quite pleased with Thai Airways.

First thing was first, hire a car. Found the car rental area in the airport terminal easy enough thanks to parallel English translations of almost every sign; perfect for the noob traveller like us.

Picked up late model Audi TT which was super nice to drive. It had a great gearbox and a beautiful flat-bottomed steering wheel generally found in Audi’s RS marquee. Steering feel was effectively nil but was perfect for weaving around the narrow side streets of Old Town.

I felt completely overwhelmed and intimidated by the driving skill and culture of the Germans – particularly the Bavarians. This was BMW home turf. Lest we forget that they drive on the ‘right’ side of the road.

Speaking of which, we made our way to BMW Welt (BMW World) just north of Old Town. As I entered, I couldn’t help but reminisce of yesteryear at the Melbourne Exhibition Centre back when we used to host the International Motor Shows; surrounded by all things car. Except this was all things BMW.

We couldn’t have wandered around for more than 5 minutes before I saw the new BMW M2 and had a little perve.

I got busted by one of the ‘curators’ and quickly picked up his bogan accent. Surprisingly, we talked for a bit, but nothing about cars – more about his move to Germany from Australia. Being tourists, he suggested we visit Augustiner-Keller, a 5000-seat beer garden not far from München Hauptbahnhof (Munich Railway Station).

The place had full on fresh vibes. It was super dope purely because it was more of a localist place. Easily confirmed by spotting the innumerable amount of guys in their office slacks and rolled up business shirts.

I can’t comment on the food at Augustiner since all I ended up with was the Bavarian version of chicken and chips. It’s not to say that it wasn’t good – it was. I was just sad because I asked for spare ribs but I guess it got lost in translation and I was too scared to make a fuss about it in front of the locals. I just wanted to fit in. Kind of ironic because I couldn’t have looked further from a local and even more so with my camera slung across.

Claudia liked the chicken.

On that same day at BMW Welt, I picked up a beautiful F82 M4 and asked the kind Frau to send me to nearest stretch of autobahn.

It took me awhile to figure out where the ‘autobahn’ was. I was thinking there would be signs but I eventually figured out by watching the speed limit signs gradually change from, 80 km/h to 120 km/h and then to a sign that just had a line through it – this meant no speed limit and we all know what that means.

I’m not sure where I topped out on the speedo. I was too scared to focus on anything else other that what was in front of me. Claudia was adamant that I did 260 km/h before I had to slam on the brakes for congestion.

On the way back, we stopped by the O.G Aldi and picked up some munchies.

Also spotted a prototype 5 series in the wild.

Will share more in another post :)

T
posts.plaintext:
To be perfectly honest, the only reason we flew into Munich was purely due to it
being the cheapest option. Though I’m not quite sure why. It may have something
to do with less taxes or fees when flying in and out of the Eurozone from
Munich.

With that said, I absolutely love Munich. There’s something about it that has a
certain charm to it. I think a large part of that could be attributed to its
vast and eclectic history. Nothing a couple of world wars can’t do to add to
your nation’s history.

We flew out of Melbourne W-DAY +1 at 1400 hours and landed at Munich W-DAY +2 at
0700 hours local time so it worked out well and calibrated to the timezone with
no jet laggage.

Claudia was quite pleased with Thai Airways.

First thing was first, hire a car. Found the car rental area in the airport
terminal easy enough thanks to parallel English translations of almost every
sign; perfect for the noob traveller like us.

Picked up late model Audi TT which was super nice to drive. It had a great
gearbox and a beautiful flat-bottomed steering wheel generally found in Audi’s
RS marquee. Steering feel was effectively nil but was perfect for weaving around
the narrow side streets of Old Town.

I felt completely overwhelmed and intimidated by the driving skill and culture
of the Germans – particularly the Bavarians. This was BMW home turf. Lest we
forget that they drive on the ‘right’ side of the road.

Speaking of which, we made our way to BMW Welt (BMW World) just north of Old
Town. As I entered, I couldn’t help but reminisce of yesteryear at the Melbourne
Exhibition Centre back when we used to host the International Motor Shows;
surrounded by all things car. Except this was all things BMW.

We couldn’t have wandered around for more than 5 minutes before I saw the new
BMW M2 and had a little perve.

I got busted by one of the ‘curators’ and quickly picked up his bogan accent.
Surprisingly, we talked for a bit, but nothing about cars – more about his move
to Germany from Australia. Being tourists, he suggested we visit
Augustiner-Keller, a 5000-seat beer garden not far from München Hauptbahnhof
(Munich Railway Station).

The place had full on fresh vibes. It was super dope purely because it was more
of a localist place. Easily confirmed by spotting the innumerable amount of guys
in their office slacks and rolled up business shirts.

I can’t comment on the food at Augustiner since all I ended up with was the
Bavarian version of chicken and chips. It’s not to say that it wasn’t good – it
was. I was just sad because I asked for spare ribs but I guess it got lost in
translation and I was too scared to make a fuss about it in front of the locals.
I just wanted to fit in. Kind of ironic because I couldn’t have looked further
from a local and even more so with my camera slung across.

Claudia liked the chicken.

On that same day at BMW Welt, I picked up a beautiful F82 M4 and asked the kind
Frau to send me to nearest stretch of autobahn.

It took me awhile to figure out where the ‘autobahn’ was. I was thinking there
would be signs but I eventually figured out by watching the speed limit signs
gradually change from, 80 km/h to 120 km/h and then to a sign that just had a
line through it – this meant no speed limit and we all know what that means.

I’m not sure where I topped out on the speedo. I was too scared to focus on
anything else other that what was in front of me. Claudia was adamant that I did
260 km/h before I had to slam on the brakes for congestion.

On the way back, we stopped by the O.G Aldi and picked up some munchies.

Also spotted a prototype 5 series in the wild.

Will share more in another post :) 

T

posts.html:
Claudia here – or should I say “Mrs. Perry”. Gosh I love how that sounds.

We arrived at Melbourne airport with ample time to have breakfast and so we filled ourselves up before boarding our plane. It was a long 8 hours but we were served so well! We flew with Thai Airways. The hostesses were just beautiful and for some reason I really appreciated the plane’s interior colour scheme of soothing pinks, purples, violets.

Despite only two or three moments of mild turbulence, I began to understand why Thai Airways’ catchphrase was ‘smooth as silk’ .
I was so glad to finally get my feet on solid ground when we stopped over at Bangkok around 10.30pm local time but I experienced what I think was vertigo for the first time. It was such a strange sensation!

It would come in intermittent spells at first but then throughout the 2 hours we spent during stopover, the vertigo progressively worsened.

The ground would feel like it was moving and whenever I’d look down to ‘check’, the floor completely spun around me and I felt like I was going to faint if I didn’t sit down quickly. At first, I diagnosed myself with hypotension and gave myself a 500ml bolus of water in an attempt to absolve myself of the dizziness. Honestly, I had never prayed so much in 24 hours.

I’m so grateful that I never actually felt nauseous mostly because I forgot to bring some Maxalon (anti-nausea medication) in my carry-on. I’m all about the prophylactic meds. Oddly enough, my vertigo subsided as soon as I stepped foot onto the connecting flight to Munich. Thanks Laaawd!

Tim slept for the most part of that connecting flight but me on the other hand, I’ve never had so much fun on a 10 hour flight! Well that’s what I wish I could say. Thankfully however, it was the red-eye out of BKK so we had a whole row of seats to ourselves; taking turns to lie down in a futile search for comfortable positions.

Oh and jetlag – ain’t nobody got time for that. We flew out of Melbourne in the arvo so we arrived at Munich Airport at 7am local time which meant we could still make the most of the day, tiring ourselves out by doing tourist-y things, and then going to bed when the locals do. Thus kicking ourselves into their time zone. Perfekt.

This still feels pretty surreal. I’m travelling with my best friend whom I just married.

posts.html:
Hallo!

There is English everywhere. He speaks English, they speak English, EVERYONE speaks English! It was quite strange to be in another country and still be seeing & hearing a fair bit of our home language around the place.

We rented a car to get around for convenience and it was honestly the best thing we did here. But then we discovered BMW Welt and Tim wanted to rent an upper echelon car for an hour… For funsies. He’s sure to expand on this in his post. All I can say about it is: gals, let your man unleash his “wild heart”. It shows him you trust him and frees you to enjoy his adventurous spirit. My philosophy is: if he’s happy, I’m happy

And why wouldn’t I let him rent a BMW M4 and drive at 260km/hr on the autobahn when he smiles like this by the end of it:

Be still my heart!

The streets of Munich are so beautiful we just don’t understand why coming here isn’t a thing like going to Japan is. It honestly felt like we had entered a movie, driving down these well maintained roads lining heritage construction.

There are many one-way streets and I’m pretty sure every single person owns a bike and rides it like it’s no one’s biznatch. Seriously though most aren’t even secured to poles or gates when not in use! Just goes to show either everyone is a saint or the custom is as common as a hipster in Brunswick on a dope summers day. And maybe this is why no one’s fat around here! I only saw 2-3 overweight humans… Interesting innet?

Hmm what else…

Oh the shopping! Well we didn’t shop as such but we did find ourselves in what seemed to be the equivalent to Melbourne’s Bourke Street.

We were going to go for dinner at a place called Hofbräuhaus, a restaurant and bar place that attracts many tourists but Tim got talking to a local called Matt at the BMW Welt. He recommended us go to a local beer garden instead, which is somewhere that not all tourists know about and is the place to be at dinner time. We absolutely prefer the locals’ choice over the tourist attractions (something we discovered about ourselves early on in our adventures) so we opted to go to this Biergarten. And plus, Matt said it fits up to 5000 people so we had to go and check it out!

Now, I’m not a beer drinker but being in Germany made it seem fitting for me to have my first one. So I did… And… It was cool I guess? Lol

These Germans though far out they drink beer like it’s nothing! You should’ve seen some of the glasses… Or should I say jugs. Buckets even! They serve beer by the litre if you want it.

I should’ve taken a pic of it so you could experience the shock I did when I saw the serving size.

In this biergarten everyone takes their plates and gets food from a canteen sorta set up, then once finished they take it to a “clean up bench” where you put the food scraps into a bin and then stack your plates, like you do on a school camp. BUT you leave your glasses on the table… The staff then go around collecting them all and place them onto the back of a ute in one huge collection and drive them back to the kitchen #efficient

We tried to take a selfie at the entrance but coz I’m not a photographer and too small, I didn’t fit:

Here’s a better selfie from Kaufingerstraße:

You can tell which pics I took and which ones Tim took…

Hey whilst you’re here, check out our collab post about the buildings we got to see here in Munich. They deserve their own space!

C.

posts.title: In the beginning
posts.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}]],"cards":[],"markups":[["a",["href","https://eugdpr.org/"]],["a",["href","https://fee.org/articles/australia-s-unprecedented-encryption-law-is-a-threat-to-global-privacy/"]]],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"It's hard to say exactly when the idea to move overseas first spawned. One thing is certain - it started with me and it had been a yearning dream from yesteryear."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Back when we were dating, I mentioned to Claudia that one day I'd love to live overseas. We almost broke up because of that. The concept of moving overseas was abhorrent to her. We were at different stages of our goals."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"For me, I think at some point on the precipice adulthood, I began to entertain visions of a life lived abroad or at least a life lived outside of Melbourne; outside of my comfort zone."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"I think the very first seed that was planted was when I travelled with my family to the US. We were in the streets of New York when my uncle's brother who was a local said I could pass as a New Yorker. I never gave it much thought but I do believe it laid down the groundwork for more inspiration over the next decade."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"To my parents the idea had been preposterous. Why would you leave everything behind? Why leave a cushy job earning a six figure salary? Why leave all your loving family behind? What are you going to do about your mortgage? What are you going to do about your cat? What about having kids? What about all your friends?"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A good quality of life was paramount to my parents values and unarguably so."],[1,[],0,0],[0,[],0,"They come from a time and generation that really left them no choice but to go out and seek a better life. My dad grew up as poor can be; ascending nearby hills with his brothers to cut and harvest woodfire in order to cook food. My mum grew up in the slums of Manilla where family was the only thing that formed an impenetrable sense of drive for survival."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"And in this case, that's the key - survival. Both our had left their homes to seek survival. It was in their best interest to move."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Today however, whilst it is also in our best interest to move, the motives behind our interest is more about opportunity than it is about survival. posts.html:
It's hard to say exactly when the idea to move overseas first spawned. One thing is certain - it started with me and it had been a yearning dream from yesteryear.

Back when we were dating, I mentioned to Claudia that one day I'd love to live overseas. We almost broke up because of that. The concept of moving overseas was abhorrent to her. We were at different stages of our goals.

For me, I think at some point on the precipice adulthood, I began to entertain visions of a life lived abroad or at least a life lived outside of Melbourne; outside of my comfort zone.

I think the very first seed that was planted was when I travelled with my family to the US. We were in the streets of New York when my uncle's brother who was a local said I could pass as a New Yorker. I never gave it much thought but I do believe it laid down the groundwork for more inspiration over the next decade.

To my parents the idea had been preposterous. Why would you leave everything behind? Why leave a cushy job earning a six figure salary? Why leave all your loving family behind? What are you going to do about your mortgage? What are you going to do about your cat? What about having kids? What about all your friends?

A good quality of life was paramount to my parents values and unarguably so.
They come from a time and generation that really left them no choice but to go out and seek a better life. My dad grew up as poor can be; ascending nearby hills with his brothers to cut and harvest woodfire in order to cook food. My mum grew up in the slums of Manilla where family was the only thing that formed an impenetrable sense of drive for survival.

And in this case, that's the key - survival. Both our had left their homes to seek survival. It was in their best interest to move.

Today however, whilst it is also in our best interest to move, the motives behind our interest is more about opportunity than it is about survival. We now live in an age that is experiencing new levels of peace & prosperity and so instead of survival, we seek  opportunity. And at the end of the day, humans are nomadic in nature.

When I finally happened upon this paradigm and explained it to my parents, it was well understood and no additional explanation was required.

In retrospect, I have tried to best rationalise the culmination of our recent move and I think it largely boils down to few moments:

In 2015, I travelled to the south island of New Zealand with my old friend Rob Tran. Curiously, experiencing the gorgeous southern alps & lakes that dotted the Canterbury and Otago regions in New Zealand were not the deciding factor to upheave our lives but it was rather the sheer distinction between what I had known for so long and what could possibly be.

Put simply, "if this is what another place is like, what more the rest of the world?".

The other contributing factor was how much I grown to despise Melbourne's, and by extension, Australia's inability to think big and make some waves in the world.
"She'll be right mate" is the embodiment of the Aussie attitude and it has kept us easy-going for a long time but it's also kept us apathetic and I couldn't see myself putting up with it for much longer.

The long and short of it is this: I have felt out of touch and lost my sense of belonging to a city and nation that has collectively lost it's sense of identity in the world and the ramifications of this have cascaded into the everyman's way of life. I'm a person that is big on vision, I look for it everywhere. I look for friends that have vision, I want to work for organisations that have big vision, I want to be a part of a church has vision for the modern age, I want to be part of a nation that has big vision for playing its part in the rest of the world. And sadly, Australia is not in tune with that wavelength and hopefully someday it might but I can't be waiting around for that to happen. The time is now.

So these philosophies installed themselves quite deeply into my head and I began to look on with envy at cities and nations all over the globe and marvelled at how progressive and innovative they were trying to be.

Just take a quick look at Europe, particularly with the recent introduction of the GDPR (https://eugdpr.org/)(General Data Protection Regulation) - while it's not perfect, it is an incredible step forward in terms of protecting the rights and privacy of all Europeans. Meanwhile in Australia we have just passed the most backward-stepping piece of legislation the world has ever seen, the Anti-Encryption Law (https://fee.org/articles/australia-s-unprecedented-encryption-law-is-a-threat-to-global-privacy/).

I digress. Ultimately, the grass was really green on the other side and I had to get there.

Fast forward to our honeymoon in Europe in 2016. We merely experienced a small taste but it was enough to convince us that we wanted to live in a place like Germany. We loved the cultural ethos, the intuitive & innovative way of life, the rich history, the proximity to other beautiful neighbouring countries, and most importantly, the autobahn.

And so we agreed to move overseas and begin our grand plans to move to Germany. We started by researching work life, making connections with people and started learning German. At first it we convinced ourselves it was doable. German's can speak English but it's not the official language.

Over time, we began to realise the futility of trying to move to country that spoke a different language. We would need to learn, not only the common tongue, but learn to speak it in a professional setting; Claudia would need to learn medical German.

So we re-evaluated our plans. If language was the barrier, the only other place to go was the UK. This is fine. We'd love to go to there. So I began throwing questions to my English colleague at the time and asked about living in Manchester.

For some reason I was convinced that Manchester would be a cool place to live. It was fast becoming a centre for culture and tech in the north of England. Also, it's not London so it shouldn't be that expensive to live there. My colleague didn't discourage me but did make me wary of the extremities of the weather up north. It can get incredibly cold.

Never mind that because recruiters started getting in touch with me about tech jobs in Manchester - though they never really progressed because I didn't have a visa yet which I'll talk more about in another post soon.

Fast forward a period of time and we eventually decided that London would have to be the place to aim for. There would be a better chance of getting work (although just as much competition). If we could just get jobs that paid enough for us to live in central London, we would be happy. So we planned a mid-year getaway to London with the aim of scouting the city for liveability.

In June 2018, we were the upper deck of a new Routemaster heading to South Kensington  station when Claudia decided to google the idea of applying for a nursing job in London. Lo and behold, she stumbled upon a website of an organisation that did exactly what we were looking for - they would recruit nurses from overseas to work in London and the rest of the UK. They would take care of the entire process (thankfully - what a process it was!).

When we arrived back home in Melbourne, Claudia spared no time in enquiring and by the end of August 2018, Claudia received a formal letter of offer from a hospital in Chelsea that specialised in cardiology.

And so the journey officially begun.

posts.html:
To be perfectly honest, the only reason we flew into Munich was purely due to it being the cheapest option. Though I’m not quite sure why. It may have something to do with less taxes or fees when flying in and out of the Eurozone from Munich.

With that said, I absolutely love Munich. There’s something about it that has a certain charm to it. I think a large part of that could be attributed to its vast and eclectic history. Nothing a couple of world wars can’t do to add to your nation’s history.

We flew out of Melbourne W-DAY +1 at 1400 hours and landed at Munich W-DAY +2 at 0700 hours local time so it worked out well and calibrated to the timezone with no jet laggage.

Claudia was quite pleased with Thai Airways.

First thing was first, hire a car. Found the car rental area in the airport terminal easy enough thanks to parallel English translations of almost every sign; perfect for the noob traveller like us.

Picked up late model Audi TT which was super nice to drive. It had a great gearbox and a beautiful flat-bottomed steering wheel generally found in Audi’s RS marquee. Steering feel was effectively nil but was perfect for weaving around the narrow side streets of Old Town.

I felt completely overwhelmed and intimidated by the driving skill and culture of the Germans – particularly the Bavarians. This was BMW home turf. Lest we forget that they drive on the ‘right’ side of the road.

Speaking of which, we made our way to BMW Welt (BMW World) just north of Old Town. As I entered, I couldn’t help but reminisce of yesteryear at the Melbourne Exhibition Centre back when we used to host the International Motor Shows; surrounded by all things car. Except this was all things BMW.

We couldn’t have wandered around for more than 5 minutes before I saw the new BMW M2 and had a little perve.

I got busted by one of the ‘curators’ and quickly picked up his bogan accent. Surprisingly, we talked for a bit, but nothing about cars – more about his move to Germany from Australia. Being tourists, he suggested we visit Augustiner-Keller, a 5000-seat beer garden not far from München Hauptbahnhof (Munich Railway Station).

The place had full on fresh vibes. It was super dope purely because it was more of a localist place. Easily confirmed by spotting the innumerable amount of guys in their office slacks and rolled up business shirts.

I can’t comment on the food at Augustiner since all I ended up with was the Bavarian version of chicken and chips. It’s not to say that it wasn’t good – it was. I was just sad because I asked for spare ribs but I guess it got lost in translation and I was too scared to make a fuss about it in front of the locals. I just wanted to fit in. Kind of ironic because I couldn’t have looked further from a local and even more so with my camera slung across.

Claudia liked the chicken.

On that same day at BMW Welt, I picked up a beautiful F82 M4 and asked the kind Frau to send me to nearest stretch of autobahn.

It took me awhile to figure out where the ‘autobahn’ was. I was thinking there would be signs but I eventually figured out by watching the speed limit signs gradually change from, 80 km/h to 120 km/h and then to a sign that just had a line through it – this meant no speed limit and we all know what that means.

I’m not sure where I topped out on the speedo. I was too scared to focus on anything else other that what was in front of me. Claudia was adamant that I did 260 km/h before I had to slam on the brakes for congestion.

On the way back, we stopped by the O.G Aldi and picked up some munchies.

Also spotted a prototype 5 series in the wild.

Will share more in another post :)

T

Augustiner-Keller, a 5000-seat beer garden not far from München Hauptbahnhof
(Munich Railway Station).

The place had full on fresh vibes. It was super dope purely because it was more
of a localist place. Easily confirmed by spotting the innumerable amount of guys
in their office slacks and rolled up business shirts.

I can’t comment on the food at Augustiner since all I ended up with was the
Bavarian version of chicken and chips. It’s not to say that it wasn’t good – it
was. I was just sad because I asked for spare ribs but I guess it got lost in
translation and I was too scared to make a fuss about it in front of the locals.
I just wanted to fit in. Kind of ironic because I couldn’t have looked further
from a local and even more so with my camera slung across.

Claudia liked the chicken.

On that same day at BMW Welt, I picked up a beautiful F82 M4 and asked the kind
Frau to send me to nearest stretch of autobahn.

It took me awhile to figure out where the ‘autobahn’ was. I was thinking there
would be signs but I eventually figured out by watching the speed limit signs
gradually change from, 80 km/h to 120 km/h and then to a sign that just had a
line through it – this meant no speed limit and we all know what that means.

I’m not sure where I topped out on the speedo. I was too scared to focus on
anything else other that what was in front of me. Claudia was adamant that I did
260 km/h before I had to slam on the brakes for congestion.

On the way back, we stopped by the O.G Aldi and picked up some munchies.

Also spotted a prototype 5 series in the wild.

Will share more in another post :) 

T
posts.custom_excerpt: I absolutely love Munich. There’s something about it that has a certain charm to it. I think a large part of that could be attributed to its vast and eclectic history. Nothing a couple of world wars can’t do to add to your nation’s history.

posts.html:
Claudia here – or should I say “Mrs. Perry”. Gosh I love how that sounds.

We arrived at Melbourne airport with ample time to have breakfast and so we filled ourselves up before boarding our plane. It was a long 8 hours but we were served so well! We flew with Thai Airways. The hostesses were just beautiful and for some reason I really appreciated the plane’s interior colour scheme of soothing pinks, purples, violets.

Despite only two or three moments of mild turbulence, I began to understand why Thai Airways’ catchphrase was ‘smooth as silk’ .
I was so glad to finally get my feet on solid ground when we stopped over at Bangkok around 10.30pm local time but I experienced what I think was vertigo for the first time. It was such a strange sensation!

It would come in intermittent spells at first but then throughout the 2 hours we spent during stopover, the vertigo progressively worsened.

The ground would feel like it was moving and whenever I’d look down to ‘check’, the floor completely spun around me and I felt like I was going to faint if I didn’t sit down quickly. At first, I diagnosed myself with hypotension and gave myself a 500ml bolus of water in an attempt to absolve myself of the dizziness. Honestly, I had never prayed so much in 24 hours.

I’m so grateful that I never actually felt nauseous mostly because I forgot to bring some Maxalon (anti-nausea medication) in my carry-on. I’m all about the prophylactic meds. Oddly enough, my vertigo subsided as soon as I stepped foot onto the connecting flight to Munich. Thanks Laaawd!

Tim slept for the most part of that connecting flight but me on the other hand, I’ve never had so much fun on a 10 hour flight! Well that’s what I wish I could say. Thankfully however, it was the red-eye out of BKK so we had a whole row of seats to ourselves; taking turns to lie down in a futile search for comfortable positions.

Oh and jetlag – ain’t nobody got time for that. We flew out of Melbourne in the arvo so we arrived at Munich Airport at 7am local time which meant we could still make the most of the day, tiring ourselves out by doing tourist-y things, and then going to bed when the locals do. Thus kicking ourselves into their time zone. Perfekt.

This still feels pretty surreal. I’m travelling with my best friend whom I just married.

posts.html:
Hallo!

There is English everywhere. He speaks English, they speak English, EVERYONE speaks English! It was quite strange to be in another country and still be seeing & hearing a fair bit of our home language around the place.

We rented a car to get around for convenience and it was honestly the best thing we did here. But then we discovered BMW Welt and Tim wanted to rent an upper echelon car for an hour… For funsies. He’s sure to expand on this in his post. All I can say about it is: gals, let your man unleash his “wild heart”. It shows him you trust him and frees you to enjoy his adventurous spirit. My philosophy is: if he’s happy, I’m happy

And why wouldn’t I let him rent a BMW M4 and drive at 260km/hr on the autobahn when he smiles like this by the end of it:

Be still my heart!

The streets of Munich are so beautiful we just don’t understand why coming here isn’t a thing like going to Japan is. It honestly felt like we had entered a movie, driving down these well maintained roads lining heritage construction.

There are many one-way streets and I’m pretty sure every single person owns a bike and rides it like it’s no one’s biznatch. Seriously though most aren’t even secured to poles or gates when not in use! Just goes to show either everyone is a saint or the custom is as common as a hipster in Brunswick on a dope summers day. And maybe this is why no one’s fat around here! I only saw 2-3 overweight humans… Interesting innet?

Hmm what else…

Oh the shopping! Well we didn’t shop as such but we did find ourselves in what seemed to be the equivalent to Melbourne’s Bourke Street.

We were going to go for dinner at a place called Hofbräuhaus, a restaurant and bar place that attracts many tourists but Tim got talking to a local called Matt at the BMW Welt. He recommended us go to a local beer garden instead, which is somewhere that not all tourists know about and is the place to be at dinner time. We absolutely prefer the locals’ choice over the tourist attractions (something we discovered about ourselves early on in our adventures) so we opted to go to this Biergarten. And plus, Matt said it fits up to 5000 people so we had to go and check it out!

Now, I’m not a beer drinker but being in Germany made it seem fitting for me to have my first one. So I did… And… It was cool I guess? Lol

These Germans though far out they drink beer like it’s nothing! You should’ve seen some of the glasses… Or should I say jugs. Buckets even! They serve beer by the litre if you want it.

I should’ve taken a pic of it so you could experience the shock I did when I saw the serving size.

In this biergarten everyone takes their plates and gets food from a canteen sorta set up, then once finished they take it to a “clean up bench” where you put the food scraps into a bin and then stack your plates, like you do on a school camp. BUT you leave your glasses on the table… The staff then go around collecting them all and place them onto the back of a ute in one huge collection and drive them back to the kitchen #efficient

We tried to take a selfie at the entrance but coz I’m not a photographer and too small, I didn’t fit:

Here’s a better selfie from Kaufingerstraße:

You can tell which pics I took and which ones Tim took…

Hey whilst you’re here, check out our collab post about the buildings we got to see here in Munich. They deserve their own space!

C.

{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}]],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"It's hard to say exactly when the idea to move overseas first spawned. One thing is for sure - it started with me and it had been a yearning dream from yesteryear."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"I think at some point in between the precipice of early-to-mid twenties I began to entertain visions of a life lived abroad or at least a life lived outside of Melbourne; outside of my comfort zone."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"To my parents the idea had been preposterous. Why would you leave everything behind? Why leave a cushy job earning a six figure salary? Why leave all your loving family behind? How can you leave your mortgage behind? What are you going to do about your cat? What about having kids? You just got connected with a good group of people at church - how can you leave that?"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A good quality of life was paramount to my parents values and unarguably so."],[1,[],0,0],[0,[],0,"They come from a time and generation that really left them no choice but to go out and seek a better life. My dad grew up as poor can be; ascending nearby hills with his brothers to cut and harvest woodfire in order to cook food. My mum grew up in the slums of Manilla where family was the only thing that formed an impenetrable sense of drive for survival."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"And in this case, that's the key - survival. Both our had left their homes to seek survival. It was in their best interest to move."],[1,[],0,1],[0,[],0,"Today however, whilst it is also in our best interest to move, the motives behind our interest is rather more about opportunity than it is about survival. We now live in an age that is experiencing new levels of peace & prosperity and so instead of survival, we seek  opportunity."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"We as humans will only do things based on either of the two dispositions."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"When I finally happened upon this paradigm and explained it to my parents, it was well understood and no additional explanation was required."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In retrospect, I have tried to best rationalise the culmination of our recent move and I think it largely boils down to a handful of events and moments:"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In 2015, I travelled to the south island of New Zealand with my old friend Rob Tran. Curiously, the southern alps and lakes that dotted the Canterbury and Otago regions in New Zealand were not solely responsible for the deciding factor to upheave our lives but it was the sheer distinction between what I known for so long and could possibly be."],[1,[],0,2],[0,[],0,"In simple terms, \"if this is what another place is like, what more the rest of the world\"."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The other moment responsible for causing the urge to move was rather less a singular moment but more of a sequence of or near-constant reminders of how much I despised Melbourne's infrastructure. I'm sure many close to me back home will be well versed in my passionate tirades on the hopelessly rampant train delays & cancellations."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"But it wasn't just Melbourne's infrastructure, it was the general way of life. What did it mean to be an Australian? For me, not much due to recent times. We are the butt-end of every joke. We haven't had decent leadership since 2007 - how can an organisation, let alone a nation, function well without good leadership? The answer: it doesn't."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"I digress. The long and short of it is this: I have felt out of touch and lost my sense of belonging to a nation that has collectively lost it's sense of identity in the world and the ramifications of this have cascaded into the everyman's way of life. I'm a person that is big on vision, I look for it everywhere. I look for friends that have vision, I want to work for organisations that have big vision, I want to be a part of a church has vision for the modern age, I want to be part of a nation that has big vision for playing its part in the rest of the world. And sadly, Australia is not in tune with that wavelength and hopefully someday it might but I can't be waiting around for that to happen. The time is now."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"So these philosophies installed themselves quite deeply into my head and I began look enviously at cities and nations that were progressive, innovative and"]]]]}

It had a great gearbox and a beautiful flat-bottomed steering wheel generally found in Audi’s RS marquee. Surprisingly, we talked for a bit, but nothing about cars – more about his move to Germany from Australia. It was super dope purely because it was more of a localist place. Easily confirmed by spotting the innumerable amount of guys in their office slacks and rolled up business shirts."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"I can’t comment on the food at Augustiner since all I ended up with was the Bavarian version of chicken and chips. It’s not to say that it wasn’t good – it was. I was just sad because I asked for spare ribs but I guess it got lost in translation and I was too scared to make a fuss about it in front of the locals. I just wanted to fit in. Kind of ironic because I couldn’t have looked further from a local and even more so with my camera slung across."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Claudia liked the chicken."]]],[10,6],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"On that same day at BMW Welt, I picked up a beautiful F82 M4 and asked the kind Frau to send me to nearest stretch of autobahn."]]],[10,7],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"It took me awhile to figure out where the ‘autobahn’ was. I was thinking there would be signs but I eventually figured out by watching the speed limit signs gradually change from, 80 km/h to 120 km/h and then to a sign that just had a line through it – this meant no speed limit and we all know what that means."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"I’m not sure where I topped out on the speedo. I was too scared to focus on anything else other that what was in front of me. Claudia was adamant that I did 260 km/h before I had to slam on the brakes for congestion."]]],[10,8],[1,"p",[]]]}

Germany's version of Melbourne's Bourke St, "Kaufingerstraße" in Marienplatz is the most relaxing experience despite it being a shopper's dream. To our surprise we found it only got busy at 5pm when all the buskers came out and the walkways filled up with people. It was a beautiful mix of modern lifestyle within amazing heritage architecture. Also, Maccas here is green and yellow 🤔 and I only saw like 2-3 fat people... We think it's coz everyone rides bikes around here, like literally everyone 🚴🏻 #munichgermany #veryperrywedding #marriedlifeisadream

A post shared by Claudia Perry (@claudiaperryyy) on Jun 30, 2016 at 6:35am PDT

Germany's version of Melbourne's Bourke St, "Kaufingerstraße" in Marienplatz is the most relaxing experience despite it being a shopper's dream. To our surprise we found it only got busy at 5pm when all the buskers came out and the walkways filled up with people. It was a beautiful mix of modern lifestyle within amazing heritage architecture. Also, Maccas here is green and yellow 🤔 and I only saw like 2-3 fat people... We think it's coz everyone rides bikes around here, like literally everyone 🚴🏻 #munichgermany #veryperrywedding #marriedlifeisadream

{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}]],"cards":[],"markups":[["a",["href","https://eugdpr.org/"]],["a",["href","https://fee.org/articles/australia-s-unprecedented-encryption-law-is-a-threat-to-global-privacy/"]]],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"It's hard to say exactly when the idea to move overseas first spawned. One thing is certain - it started with me and it had been a yearning dream from yesteryear."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Back when we were dating, I mentioned to Claudia that one day I'd love to live overseas. We almost broke up because of that. The concept of moving overseas was abhorrent to her. We were at different stages of our goals."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"For me, I think at some point on the precipice adulthood, I began to entertain visions of a life lived abroad or at least a life lived outside of Melbourne; outside of my comfort zone."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"I think the very first seed that was planted was when I travelled with my family to the US. We were in the streets of New York when my uncle's brother who was a local said I could pass as a New Yorker. I never gave it much thought but I do believe it laid down the groundwork for more inspiration over the next decade."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"To my parents the idea had been preposterous. Why would you leave everything behind? Why leave a cushy job earning a six figure salary? Why leave all your loving family behind? What are you going to do about your mortgage? What are you going to do about your cat? What about having kids? What about all your friends?"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A good quality of life was paramount to my parents values and unarguably so."],[1,[],0,0],[0,[],0,"They come from a time and generation that really left them no choice but to go out and seek a better life. My dad grew up as poor can be; ascending nearby hills with his brothers to cut and harvest woodfire in order to cook food. My mum grew up in the slums of Manilla where family was the only thing that formed an impenetrable sense of drive for survival."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"And in this case, that's the key - survival. Both our had left their homes to seek survival. It was in their best interest to move."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Today however, whilst it is also in our best interest to move, the motives behind our interest is more about opportunity than it is about survival. We now live in an age that is experiencing new levels of peace & prosperity and so instead of survival, we seek  opportunity. And at the end of the day, humans are nomadic in nature."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"When I finally happened upon this paradigm and explained it to my parents, it was well understood and no additional explanation was required."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In retrospect, I have tried to best rationalise the culmination of our recent move and I think it largely boils down to few moments:"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In 2015, I travelled to the south island of New Zealand with my old friend Rob Tran. Curiously, experiencing the gorgeous southern alps & lakes that dotted the Canterbury and Otago regions in New Zealand were not the deciding factor to upheave our lives but it was rather the sheer distinction between what I had known for so long and what could possibly be."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Put simply, \"if this is what another place is like, what more the rest of the world?\"."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The other contributing factor was how much I grown to despise Melbourne's, and by extension, Australia's inability to think big and make some waves in the world."],[1,[],0,1],[0,[],0,"\"She'll be right mate\" is the embodiment of the Aussie attitude and it has kept us easy-going for a long time but it's also kept us apathetic and I couldn't see myself putting up with it for much longer."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The long and short of it is this: I have felt out of touch and lost my sense of belonging to a city and nation that has collectively lost it's sense of identity in the world and the ramifications of this have cascaded into the everyman's way of life. I'm a person that is big on vision, I look for it everywhere. I look for friends that have vision, I want to work for organisations that have big vision, I want to be a part of a church has vision for the modern age, I want to be part of a nation that has big vision for playing its part in the rest of the world. And sadly, Australia is not in tune with that wavelength and hopefully someday it might but I can't be waiting around for that to happen. The time is now."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"So these philosophies installed themselves quite deeply into my head and I began to look on with envy at cities and nations all over the globe and marvelled at how progressive and innovative they were trying to be."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Just take a quick look at Europe, particularly with the recent introduction of the GDPR ("],[0,[0],1,"https://eugdpr.org/"],[0,[],0,")(General Data Protection Regulation) - while it's not perfect, it is an incredible step forward in terms of protecting the rights and privacy of all Europeans. Meanwhile in Australia we have just passed the most backward-stepping piece of legislation the world has ever seen, the Anti-Encryption Law ("],[0,[1],1,"https://fee.org/articles/australia-s-unprecedented-encryption-law-is-a-threat-to-global-privacy/"],[0,[],0,")."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"I digress. Ultimately, the grass was really green on the other side and I had to get there."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Fast forward to our honeymoon in Europe in 2016. We merely experienced a small taste but it was enough to convince us that we wanted to live in a place like Germany. We loved the cultural ethos, the intuitive & innovative way of life, the rich history, the proximity to other beautiful neighbouring countries, and most importantly, the autobahn."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"And so we agreed to move overseas and begin our grand plans to move to Germany. We started by researching work life, making connections with people and started learning German. At first it we convinced ourselves it was doable. German's can speak English but it's not the official language."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Over time, we began to realise the futility of trying to move to country that spoke a different language. We would need to learn, not only the common tongue, but learn to speak it in a professional setting; Claudia would need to learn medical German."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"So we re-evaluated our plans. If language was the barrier, the only other place to go was the UK. This is fine. We'd love to go to there. So I began throwing questions to my English colleague at the time and asked about living in Manchester."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"For some reason I was convinced that Manchester would be a cool place to live. It was fast becoming a centre for culture and tech in the north of England. Also, it's not London so it shouldn't be that expensive to live there. My colleague didn't discourage me but did make me wary of the extremities of the weather up north. It can get incredibly cold."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Never mind that because recruiters started getting in touch with me about tech jobs in Manchester - though they never really progressed because I didn't have a visa yet which I'll talk more about in another post soon."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Fast forward a period of time and we eventually decided that London would have to be the place to aim for. There would be a better chance of getting work (although just as much competition). If we could just get jobs that paid enough for us to live in central London, we would be happy. So we planned a mid-year getaway to London with the aim of scouting the city for liveability."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In June 2018, we were the upper deck of a new Routemaster heading to South Kensington  station when Claudia decided to google the idea of applying for a nursing job in London. Lo and behold, she stumbled upon a website of an organisation that did exactly what we were looking for - they would recruit nurses from overseas to work in London and the rest of the UK. They would take care of the entire process (thankfully - what a process it was!)."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"When we arrived back home in Melbourne, Claudia spared no time in enquiring and by the end of August 2018, Claudia received a formal letter of offer from a hospital in Chelsea that specialised in cardiology."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"And so the journey officially begun."]]]]}
